Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: Steady rain and frequent lane changes from nearby cars raise the risk of sudden stops
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: Rain pattered against my windshield as I navigated the slick streets, my hands tight on the wheel. As a taxi driver, I was trained to keep calm, follow every traffic law, and drive defensively—especially on nights like this, when headlights blurred and cars darted unpredictably. But my phone buzzed urgently on the seat beside me. Messages from fellow activists flashed across the screen: police had started blocking the protest exits, and panic was spreading. I was supposed to help coordinate a safe response, to make sure everyone got out without confrontation. My mind raced. If I pulled over to help, I’d risk blocking traffic or causing an accident in these dangerous conditions. If I kept driving, I’d be abandoning my friends when they needed me most. The weight of both roles pressed down on me—responsible driver, committed activist—each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time. My heart pounded as I approached the next intersection, torn between the rules of the road and the call to action.
